task.summary: Default task
Removed uneeded dump() statement.

Added ''Categories Explained' and '9 Rules for the 6 Acts' Closes #29.
Part of the wider re-arrangement and discussion, see #28.

Re-arranged content as per issue #28 - added links to two new pages, 'Categories Explained' and '9 Rules for the 6 Acts', ready to be used for the animated splash.
Closed #28.
Customised colours. Whilst not final, now that the mechanism is there this closes #7.

Fixed an issue where the message sent back to the client upon voting on a proposal with no previous votes was an array rather than a string, causing "toast" (the notification system) to fail and raise a JS error in the console.
Closed #27.

With this commit the client connection to the server stays open (keeps alive) on;y of the .env file explicitly states `KEEP_ALIVE=true`.
This therefore closes #22.
Added Matomon analytics JS code at the botom of master layout as per #33. Similarly Google analytics code might need adding, so this ticket will remain open for the time being.

Handling events from outside React's scope (in the DOM) - with experimental experimental syntax 'classProperties'
with the addition of "@babel/preset-env" in babel's configuration in `composer.json`
It looks like this will ve resolving issue #4 which has been on the cards for aeons without having to migrate the buttons into the react component. Currently it simply reports to the console the infamous debug line.

Placeholder commit.
The important bit is migrated the Categories from Laravel blade to React Fragment
Loads of other work included too.
Social media buttons (main Six Acts) in the sidebar. Closed #35.

The categories list is now <Fragment> of the Proposals component, in the portal paelance. It means that even though it sits outside the component's DOM tree, it's part of it for all concerned. It can now have its own "synthetic" events bubbling up the same way as all others within the component and in the right order. I don't know why this portal solution is not advocated for a loose model of development, rather than promoting an architecture which requires the ho=le page to be a single react component.
I still don't know hpw ro attach a handler to it though.

Category filtering is now fully functioning. Unlike the implementation planned originally, this uses native React ways of achieving this. It sets the selected flags on the categories, themselves store in the application's state. From that point on, any change in that state will trigger a 'tree shakeup' and a diff. and consequently a smooth refresh of the main area, the listing of the proposals.
Note that whilst I looked at listening at events external to the Proposal component's tree, it transpired that one can attach portals to a component which can live anywhere in the page. It's a much nicer way of achieving this and, after biting the original bullet, it's actually much easier as it belongs to the same cluster of logic as the main component
In addition, the buttons now don't turn into outlines when unselected, they simply appear faded.
Proudly closed #4.

Make social buttons [facebook, twitter] in sidebar open respective social deserts in new window.
Closed #37

Made buttons in the proposal form look and feel the same as the category filter ones. The only difference here is that this was achieved with the use of cash, an absurdly small jQuery alternative for modern browsers. All buttons get set to pale, then the one clicked changes class to 'full' (as in opacity.) Similarly, single hidden textbox carries the value of the currently selected categoryId, to be posted to the post processor `POST /propose`. categoryId now needs adding to the validation rules (new ticket #38)and job's done.
Closed #36.

Successfully add categoryId to the newly inserted proposals. Removed cash.js - as much as I prefer it to jQury, jQuery is already loaded and the mixing of the two caused only problems. The categoryId is now a Bulma is-hidden text field, rather than an input element of type hidden, with lte advantages this has to offer. Closed #38

Have added Matomo analytics, accessible from our intranet and Google analytis, assuing the code I saw in photo is correct.
Closed #33.
Changing http to https does the job. Closed #41.

Added word counter function and indicator in proposal page.
Closed #31.

Added splash pages seen for now "naked" at /intro - closed #39
Added fullpage layout with no header, footer, sidebar etc (but with the rest of the framework wired in.) - closed #42
Fixed theGoogle urchin issue (following the https one solved not long ago.) It appears that urchin is deprecated. More testing is needed.
Pre-splash commit, lest we need to pedal back quickly.

This commit now adds a splash screen, animated as if it were, to the home page. That is, when a user visits, the main page gets softened out and a "modal" content block appears with the content we agreed. I had a much more jazzy animation in mind, this is merely a transition but it certainly does the job of
* Attracting media-busy visitor's attention for a few seconds * Conveying the message * Offering more than just a glimpse of what's behind (the overlay is semi-transparent.)
I could certainly do more work on the transitions, animation and transparency but those improvements can wait as there are a couple of other more urgent issues:
#45 Disable menu items whilst on countdown mode (i.e. with the splash screen on) #44 Add a “countdown timer” to the splash screen.
This closes #40 as it provides the splash screen, it does a transition of sorts, which might become more of an animation if I get a minute, and remaining elements of it have now been transferred to new individual tickets (#44, #45).

Added countdown timer. After spending a good 30 minutes refreshing my milliseconds, 60 minutes per hour, 24 hours per day etc, I came across.. this https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-countdown-now.
It's obscene, everything has been done already (Umberto Eco, Postmodernism.)
Closed #44.

Wrapped <Countdown /> control in if (element) statement to fix the obvious error that occured when the splashscreen wasn't rendered and the Proposals was still attaching the control to the DOM.
Closed #46.

This is an end-of-the day commit which contains fixes and work for various tickets.
Among many other issues and fixes:
Closed #59. Closed #58.

This correctly sets the callback URL for the social media login handlers to the right host - that is, the host as set in .env file, for security reasons.
Closed #64.

This fixes the issue where no appropriate message was returned to the client when aguest (not logged in visitor) attempted to vote.
Closed #60.

This commit disables menu items from the site that shouldn't be clickable pre-launch. As such, it closes #63. I will leave #45 open not because it's not "fixed" but because we may want to add/remove items in the near future.
Updated contents of about page as per document attached to ticket #47 and so closed #47.
Added collapse/expand functionality to the Proposals listing and so I closed #66.

Social buttons added and wired. The content probably can do with testing various parameters (by content I mean the stuff we pass onto twitter and facebook respectively) bit I am closing the issue now because it works and because those customisations are at least hard, if not impossible. I will open another ticket relating to a glossy printable version of the expanded Action (its details page, such as https://beta.sixacts.org/proposal/2) and how best to refer to it in FB and twitter, but in terms of social sharing of a proposal this commit closes #68. You can go live and we carry on improving! I shall be deploying this work now.
Fixed the copy/pasted and thus wrong headings in about page.

Direct routes to signin, login, register, profile and propose are now disabled when the LAUNCH variable for the site instance is set to false (that is, the site hasn't launched yet.) This closes #69, truly allowing us to go live with no fear as there is no way for punters to bypass the filter - before it was only disable at the menu but one could still type https://oursite.org/register in the location bar and get there directly.

This commit closes issue #69 - diable direct access to URL that should not be available during the pre-launch period. In addition, it closes #70 - make the Matomo analytics siteId a variable specific to the instance (i.e. beta, live).
Copy Matomo code snippet ato all three master layouts.
Improved the truncate function used for shortening the Proposal's blurb in man listing page (home page) using Lodash's truncate.

Removed hashtag from href of okus minus buttons, thus preventing the page from scrolling up/down when said buttons are clicked whilst viewing proposals further down (i.e. after scrolling.) This closes #71.
Also, removed various `js` `console.log` statements which might give an idea to savvy users about API access points, socket services etc.

Added migration to create the `delete_orphaned_votes` trigger on the Proposals table so that when a proposal gets deleted so do the votes that were attached to it.
Closed #72.
Added slugify function SQL server to generate human readable "keys" for showing proposals, categories etc in PDF/print/facebook and twitter links.

Added migrations for creating * RDMBS function to generate 'slugs' from a string, e.g. title or name * ProposalView to expose Proposals in the API with the slug
These will come in handy in the proposal's details page, which will in turn feed into the print, facebook, twitter link, and PDF. It will also make the site slightly more SEO friendly.
Use ProposalView in api/proposals so we fetch based on slug. Altered the main view and the social sharers to point to /site/proposal/slug.
Adding Google and other search engine specific SSR view of main page to deal with the indexing conundrum.

More work done on the vanilla view of the site, depending on a Cache variable SSR set to true or false. The goal here being to have the site indexed, as I can't get the React rendered proposal links to appear in the final DOM of the main page. It is also possible that this version of the site can be switched on for browsers that indicate poor support of Javascript, but that's quite hard to conclude just out of the User-agent string. Looking into it.
Remove unnecessary debug line which only causes problems in non-dev environments.
Added links to plain/full version of site to play nicely with the crawlers - no cheating then.
Remove funny debug routes from repo.
Pre-render the content before React takes over.
Commit before attempting to add uglify

Load javscript carefully to get home page always populated.
Closed #73
